algorithm_technique: Iterate through all possible 2x2 subgrids and check color counts.
For each 2x2 subgrid, count 'B' and 'W'. If counts are 3 and 1, changing one cell makes it monochromatic.
problem_summary_simple: Can we make a 2x2 square of the same color by changing at most one cell?
problem_summary_technical: Examine all 2x2 subgrids. If a subgrid has 3 of one color and 1 of another, changing the single cell satisfies the condition.
key_insights: The grid size is fixed at 3x3, so the number of 2x2 subgrids is small (4).
For each 2x2 subgrid, we need to check if it's already monochromatic or can become monochromatic with one change.
A subgrid can become monochromatic if it has 3 cells of one color and 1 of another.
